points: The human skeletal system is made up of 206 bones.
It consists of two main parts: the axial skeleton (80 bones) that includes the skull, vertebral column, and rib cage, and the appendicular skeleton (126 bones) which comprises limb bones and girdles.
notes.title: Components of the Skeletal System

points: Support: Bones provide a framework that supports the body and maintains its shape.
Protection: Bones such as the skull and rib cage protect vital organs from injury.
Movement: Bones, muscles, and joints facilitate body movements.
Mineral Storage: Bones act as reservoirs for minerals like calcium and phosphorus.
Blood Cell Production: Red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets are produced in the red marrow of some bones.
notes.title: Functions of the Skeletal System

points: Long Bones: Found in arms and legs, they support weight and facilitate movement.
Short Bones: Provide stability and some movement; found in the wrist and ankle.
Flat Bones: Protect internal organs and provide surface for muscle attachment; includes skull, ribs, and sternum.
Irregular Bones: Have complex shapes to provide protection and support; examples include vertebrae and facial bones.
Sesamoid Bones: Embedded in tendons; protect them from stress and wear; the patella is a common example.
notes.title: Types of Bones

points: Compact Bone: Dense and hard exterior surface of the bone which provides strength.
Spongy Bone: Lighter and less dense than compact bone, found at the ends of long bones and in the inner layer of flat bones.
Bone Marrow: Soft tissue inside bones, two types - red marrow (involved in blood cell production) and yellow marrow (stores fat).
notes.title: Bone Structure

points: Fibrous Joints: Fixed joints where bones are united by fibrous tissue, allowing little or no movement, e.g., sutures in the skull.
Cartilaginous Joints: Slightly moveable, connected entirely by cartilage, e.g., joints between vertebrae in the spine.
Synovial Joints: Highly moveable joints characterized by a fluid-filled synovial cavity between the articulating bones, e.g., hinge joints like the elbow and knee.
notes.title: Types of Joints

points: Articular Cartilage: A smooth, white tissue that covers the ends of bones where they come together to form joints.
Synovial Membrane: Lines the joint and secretes synovial fluid for lubrication.
Joint Capsule: Fibrous tissue that encloses the joint cavity and provides stability.
Synovial Fluid: Lubricates the joint, reduces friction, and absorbs shocks.
notes.title: Structure of Synovial Joint

points: Provide mechanical support to the skeleton, enabling body movements.

Protect the bones by absorbing shocks during movements.

notes.title: Common Muscular Disorders
points: Myasthenia Gravis: An autoimmune disorder causing weakness and rapid fatigue of muscles due to impaired communication between nerves and muscles.
Muscular Dystrophy: A group of genetic disorders leading to progressive muscle degeneration and weakness, primarily affecting voluntary muscles.

notes.title: Common Skeletal Disorders
points: Arthritis: Inflammatory joint disorder involving pain, swelling, stiffness, and reduced motion in joints. Common types include osteoarthritis (degenerative joint disease) and rheumatoid arthritis (autoimmune disease).

Osteoporosis: A condition characterized by decreased bone mass and density, leading to enhanced bone fragility and increased fracture risk, often due to hormonal changes, or deficiency of calcium or vitamin D.

notes.title: Treatment and Management
points: Physical Therapy: Engaging in exercises to strengthen muscles and enhance joint flexibility, crucial for conditions like arthritis and mild muscular dystrophies.
Medications and Surgery: Use of anti-inflammatory drugs, immune suppressors in autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, and surgical interventions for severe cases.

points: The heart produces Atrial Natriuretic Peptide (ANP) which helps regulate blood pressure and fluid balance.
ANP works by reducing the water, sodium, and fat loads in the bloodstream, effectively reducing blood volume and pressure.
It inhibits the functions of the renin-angiotensin system and reduces blood vessel constriction, which lowers blood pressure.

points: Steroid hormones: Lipid-soluble molecules that can pass through cell membranes and bind to intracellular receptors.
Peptide hormones: Water-soluble molecules that bind to cell surface receptors and work through secondary messenger systems.

points: Steroid hormones diffuse through the cell membrane and bind to specific receptor proteins in the cytoplasm or nucleus.

points: Peptide hormones bind to receptors on the cell surface, activating a cascade of secondary messengers, such as cAMP, IP3, and DAG.
